projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts encodes the edition of each play by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine in TEI Simple. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptionss and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter young Bertram Count of Rossillion, his mother the Countess, and Helen, Lord Lafew, all in black.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
In delivering my son from me, I bury a second
husband.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
And I in going, madam, weep o’er my
father’s death anew; but I must attend his Majesty’s
command, to whom I am now in ward, evermore
in subjection.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
You shall find of the King a husband, madam;
you, sir, a father. He that so generally is at all times
good must of necessity hold his virtue to you,
whose worthiness would stir it up where it wanted
rather than lack it where there is such abundance.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
What hope is there of his Majesty’s
amendment?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
He hath abandoned his physicians, madam,
under whose practices he hath persecuted time
with hope, and finds no other advantage in the
process but only the losing of hope by time.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
This young gentlewoman had a father— O,
that “ had,” how sad a passage ’tis!— whose skill
was almost as great as his honesty; had it stretched
so far, would have made nature immortal, and
death should have play for lack of work. Would for
the King’s sake he were living! I think it would be
the death of the King’s disease.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
How called you the man you speak of,
madam?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it
was his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
He was excellent indeed, madam. The King
very lately spoke of him admiringly, and mourningly.
He was skillful enough to have lived still, if
knowledge could be set up against mortality.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
What is it, my good lord, the King languishes
of?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: A fistula, my lord.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I heard not of it before.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
I would it were not notorious.— Was this gentlewoman
the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to
my overlooking. I have those hopes of her good
that her education promises. Her dispositions she
inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer; for where an
unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there
commendations go with pity— they are virtues and
traitors too. In her they are the better for their simpleness.
She derives her honesty and achieves her
goodness.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Your commendations, madam, get from her
tears.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
’Tis the best brine a maiden can season her
praise in. The remembrance of her father never
approaches her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows
takes all livelihood from her cheek.— No
more of this, Helena. Go to. No more, lest it be
rather thought you affect a sorrow than to have—

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
excessive grief the enemy to the living.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
If the living be enemy to the grief, the
excess makes it soon mortal.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: How understand we that?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Be thou blessed, Bertram, and succeed thy father
In manners as in shape. Thy blood and virtue
Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness
Share with thy birthright. Love all, trust a few,
Do wrong to none. Be able for thine enemy
Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend
Under thy own life’s key Be checked for silence,
But never taxed for speech. What heaven more will,
That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down,
Fall on thy head. To Lafew. Farewell, my lord.
’Tis an unseasoned courtier. Good my lord,
Advise him.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: He cannot want the best that shall
Attend his love.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Heaven bless him.— Farewell, Bertram.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
The best wishes that can be forged in your
thoughts be servants to you.

To Helen. Be comfortable to my mother, your
mistress, and make much of her.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Farewell, pretty lady. You must hold the credit
of your father.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: O, were that all! I think not on my father,
And these great tears grace his remembrance more
Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
I have forgot him. My imagination
Carries no favor in ’t but Bertram’s.
I am undone. There is no living, none,
If Bertram be away. ’Twere all one
That I should love a bright particular star
And think to wed it, he is so above me.
In his bright radiance and collateral light
Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.
Th’ ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
The hind that would be mated by the lion
Must die for love. ’Twas pretty, though a plague,
To see him every hour, to sit and draw
His archèd brows, his hawking eye, his curls
In our heart’s table— heart too capable
Of every line and trick of his sweet favor.
But now he’s gone, and my idolatrous fancy
Must sanctify his relics. Who comes here?
One that goes with him. I love him for his sake,
And yet I know him a notorious liar,
Think him a great way fool, solely a coward.
Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him
That they take place when virtue’s steely bones
Looks bleak i’ th’ cold wind. Withal, full oft we see
Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Save you, fair queen.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And you, monarch.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And no.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Are you meditating on virginity?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you; let
me ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity.
How may we barricado it against him?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Keep him out.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
But he assails, and our virginity, though
valiant in the defense, yet is weak. Unfold to us
some warlike resistance.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
There is none. Man setting down before you
will undermine you and blow you up.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
Bless our poor virginity from underminers and
blowers-up! Is there no military policy how virgins
might blow up men?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Virginity being blown down, man will
quicklier be blown up. Marry, in blowing him
down again, with the breach yourselves made you
lose your city. It is not politic in the commonwealth
of nature to preserve virginity. Loss of virginity
is rational increase, and there was never
virgin got till virginity was first lost. That you
were made of is metal to make virgins. Virginity by
being once lost may be ten times found; by being
ever kept, it is ever lost. ’Tis too cold a companion.
Away with ’t.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
I will stand for ’t a little, though therefore I
die a virgin.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
There’s little can be said in ’t. ’Tis against the
rule of nature. To speak on the part of virginity is
to accuse your mothers, which is most infallible
disobedience. He that hangs himself is a virgin;
virginity murders itself and should be buried in
highways out of all sanctified limit as a desperate
offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites,
much like a cheese, consumes itself to the very
paring, and so dies with feeding his own stomach.
Besides, virginity is peevish, proud, idle, made of
self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the
canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but lose by
’t. Out with ’t! Within ten year it will make itself
two, which is a goodly increase, and the principal
itself not much the worse. Away with ’t!

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own
liking?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Let me see. Marry, ill, to like him that ne’er
it likes. ’Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with
lying; the longer kept, the less worth. Off with ’t
while ’tis vendible; answer the time of request. Virginity,
like an old courtier, wears her cap out of
fashion, richly suited but unsuitable, just like the
brooch and the toothpick, which wear not now.
Your date is better in your pie and your porridge
than in your cheek. And your virginity, your old
virginity, is like one of our French withered pears:
it looks ill, it eats dryly; marry, ’tis a withered pear.
It was formerly better, marry, yet ’tis a withered
pear. Will you anything with it?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Not my virginity, yet—
There shall your master have a thousand loves,
A mother, and a mistress, and a friend,
A phoenix, captain, and an enemy,
A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,
A counselor, a traitress, and a dear;
His humble ambition, proud humility,
His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,
His faith, his sweet disaster, with a world
Of pretty, fond adoptious christendoms
That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he—
I know not what he shall. God send him well.
The court’s a learning place, and he is one—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: What one, i’ faith?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: That I wish well. ’Tis pity—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: What’s pity?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: That wishing well had not a body in ’t
Which might be felt, that we, the poorer born,
Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,
Might with effects of them follow our friends
And show what we alone must think, which never
Returns us thanks.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Little Helen, farewell. If I can remember
thee, I will think of thee at court.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a
charitable star.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Under Mars, I.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I especially think under Mars.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Why under Mars?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
The wars hath so kept you under that you
must needs be born under Mars.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: When he was predominant.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: When he was retrograde, I think rather.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You go so much backward when you fight.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: That’s for advantage.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
So is running away, when fear proposes the
safety. But the composition that your valor and
fear makes in you is a virtue of a good wing, and I
like the wear well.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I am so full of businesses I cannot answer
thee acutely. I will return perfect courtier, in the
which my instruction shall serve to naturalize
thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier’s counsel
and understand what advice shall thrust upon
thee, else thou diest in thine unthankfulness, and
thine ignorance makes thee away. Farewell. When
thou hast leisure, say thy prayers; when thou hast
none, remember thy friends. Get thee a good husband,
and use him as he uses thee. So, farewell.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie
Which we ascribe to heaven. The fated sky
Gives us free scope, only doth backward pull
Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
What power is it which mounts my love so high,
That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
The mightiest space in fortune nature brings
To join like likes and kiss like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose
What hath been cannot be. Who ever strove
To show her merit that did miss her love?
The King’s disease— my project may deceive me,
But my intents are fixed and will not leave me.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Flourish cornets. Enter the King of France with letters, two Lords, and divers Attendants.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: The Florentines and Senoys are by th’ ears,
Have fought with equal fortune, and continue
A braving war.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: So ’tis reported, sir.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Nay, ’tis most credible. We here receive it
A certainty vouched from our cousin Austria,
With caution that the Florentine will move us
For speedy aid, wherein our dearest friend
Prejudicates the business and would seem
To have us make denial.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: His love and wisdom,
Approved so to your Majesty, may plead
For amplest credence.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: He hath armed our answer,
And Florence is denied before he comes.
Yet for our gentlemen that mean to see
The Tuscan service, freely have they leave
To stand on either part.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: It well may serve
A nursery to our gentry, who are sick
For breathing and exploit.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: What’s he comes here?

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: It is the Count Rossillion, my good lord,
Young Bertram.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Youth, thou bear’st thy father’s face.
Frank nature, rather curious than in haste,
Hath well composed thee. Thy father’s moral parts
Mayst thou inherit too. Welcome to Paris.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: My thanks and duty are your Majesty’s.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I would I had that corporal soundness now
As when thy father and myself in friendship
First tried our soldiership. He did look far
Into the service of the time and was
Discipled of the bravest. He lasted long,
But on us both did haggish age steal on
And wore us out of act. It much repairs me
To talk of your good father. In his youth
He had the wit which I can well observe
Today in our young lords; but they may jest
Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
Ere they can hide their levity in honor.
So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness
Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were,
His equal had awaked them, and his honor,
Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him speak, and at this time
His tongue obeyed his hand. Who were below him
He used as creatures of another place
And bowed his eminent top to their low ranks,
Making them proud of his humility,
In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man
Might be a copy to these younger times,
Which, followed well, would demonstrate them now
But goers backward.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: His good remembrance, sir,
Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb.
So in approof lives not his epitaph
As in your royal speech.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Would I were with him! He would always say—
Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
He scattered not in ears, but grafted them
To grow there and to bear. “ Let me not live”—
This his good melancholy oft began
On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,
When it was out—“ Let me not live,” quoth he,
“ After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
All but new things disdain, whose judgments are
Mere fathers of their garments, whose constancies
Expire before their fashions.” This he wished.
I, after him, do after him wish too,
Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,
I quickly were dissolvèd from my hive
To give some laborers room.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: You’re lovèd, sir.
They that least lend it you shall lack you first.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I fill a place, I know ’t.— How long is ’t, count,
Since the physician at your father’s died?
He was much famed.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Some six months since, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: If he were living, I would try him yet.—
Lend me an arm.— The rest have worn me out
With several applications. Nature and sickness
Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, count.
My son’s no dearer.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Thank your Majesty.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
I will now hear. What say you of this
gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p:
Madam, the care I have had to even your
content I wish might be found in the calendar of
my past endeavors, for then we wound our modesty
and make foul the clearness of our deservings
when of ourselves we publish them.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
What does this knave here? To Fool. Get
you gone, sirrah. The complaints I have heard of
you I do not all believe. ’Tis my slowness that I do
not, for I know you lack not folly to commit them
and have ability enough to make such knaveries
yours.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
’Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor
fellow.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
No, madam, ’tis not so well that I am poor,
though many of the rich are damned. But if I may
have your Ladyship’s good will to go to the world,
Isbel the woman and I will do as we may.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: I do beg your good will in this case.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: In what case?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
In Isbel’s case and mine own. Service is no heritage,
and I think I shall never have the blessing of
God till I have issue o’ my body, for they say bairns
are blessings.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
My poor body, madam, requires it. I am driven
on by the flesh, and he must needs go that the devil
drives.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Is this all your Worship’s reason?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons, such
as they are.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: May the world know them?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you
and all flesh and blood are, and indeed I do marry
that I may repent.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Thy marriage sooner than thy wickedness.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I am out o’ friends, madam, and I hope to have
friends for my wife’s sake.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
You’re shallow, madam, in great friends, for the
knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary
of. He that ears my land spares my team and gives
me leave to in the crop; if I be his cuckold, he’s my
drudge. He that comforts my wife is the cherisher
of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh
and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves
my flesh and blood is my friend. Ergo, he that
kisses my wife is my friend. If men could be contented
to be what they are, there were no fear in
marriage, for young Charbon the Puritan and old
Poysam the Papist, howsome’er their hearts are
severed in religion, their heads are both one; they
may jowl horns together like any deer i’ th’ herd.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed and
calumnious knave?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
A prophet I, madam, and I speak the truth the
next way:

lg.l: For I the ballad will repeat
Which men full true shall find:
Your marriage comes by destiny;
Your cuckoo sings by kind.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Get you gone, sir. I’ll talk with you more
anon.

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p:
May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen
come to you. Of her I am to speak.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak
with her— Helen, I mean.

lg.l: “ Was this fair face the cause,” quoth she,
“ Why the Grecians sackèd Troy?
Fond done, done fond.
Was this King Priam’s joy?”
With that she sighèd as she stood,
With that she sighèd as she stood,
And gave this sentence then:
“ Among nine bad if one be good,
Among nine bad if one be good,
There’s yet one good in ten.”

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
What, one good in ten? You corrupt the
song, sirrah.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
One good woman in ten, madam, which is a
purifying o’ th’ song. Would God would serve the
world so all the year! We’d find no fault with the
tithe-woman if I were the parson. One in ten,
quoth he? An we might have a good woman born
but or every blazing star or at an earthquake,
’twould mend the lottery well. A man may draw his
heart out ere he pluck one.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
You’ll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command
you!

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
That man should be at woman’s command, and
yet no hurt done! Though honesty be no Puritan,
yet it will do no hurt; it will wear the surplice of
humility over the black gown of a big heart. I am
going, forsooth. The business is for Helen to come
hither.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Well, now.

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p:
I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman
entirely.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Faith, I do. Her father bequeathed her to
me, and she herself, without other advantage, may
lawfully make title to as much love as she finds.
There is more owing her than is paid, and more
shall be paid her than she’ll demand.

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p:
Madam, I was very late more near her than I
think she wished me. Alone she was and did communicate
to herself her own words to her own
ears; she thought, I dare vow for her, they touched
not any stranger sense. Her matter was she loved
your son. Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that
had put such difference betwixt their two estates;
Love no god, that would not extend his might only
where qualities were level; Dian no queen of virgins,
that would suffer her poor knight surprised
without rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward.
This she delivered in the most bitter touch
of sorrow that e’er I heard virgin exclaim in, which
I held my duty speedily to acquaint you withal,
sithence in the loss that may happen it concerns
you something to know it.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
You have discharged this honestly. Keep it
to yourself. Many likelihoods informed me of this
before, which hung so tott’ring in the balance that
I could neither believe nor misdoubt. Pray you
leave me. Stall this in your bosom, and I thank you
for your honest care. I will speak with you further
anon.

lg.l: Even so it was with me when I was young.
If ever we are nature’s, these are ours. This thorn
Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong.
Our blood to us, this to our blood is born.
It is the show and seal of nature’s truth,
Where love’s strong passion is impressed in youth.
By our remembrances of days foregone,
Such were our faults, or then we thought them none.

sp.l: Her eye is sick on ’t, I observe her now.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: What is your pleasure, madam?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: You know, Helen, I am a mother to you.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Mine honorable mistress.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Nay, a mother.
Why not a mother? When I said “ a mother,”
Methought you saw a serpent. What’s in “ mother”
That you start at it? I say I am your mother
And put you in the catalogue of those
That were enwombèd mine. ’Tis often seen
Adoption strives with nature, and choice breeds
A native slip to us from foreign seeds.
You ne’er oppressed me with a mother’s groan,
Yet I express to you a mother’s care.
God’s mercy, maiden, does it curd thy blood
To say I am thy mother? What’s the matter,
That this distempered messenger of wet,
The many-colored Iris, rounds thine eye?
Why? That you are my daughter?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: That I am not.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: I say I am your mother.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Pardon, madam.
The Count Rossillion cannot be my brother.
I am from humble, he from honored name;
No note upon my parents, his all noble.
My master, my dear lord he is, and I
His servant live and will his vassal die.
He must not be my brother.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Nor I your mother?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: You are my mother, madam. Would you were—
So that my lord your son were not my brother—
Indeed my mother! Or were you both our mothers,
I care no more for than I do for heaven,
So I were not his sister. Can ’t no other
But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law.
God shield you mean it not! “ Daughter” and “ mother”
So strive upon your pulse. What, pale again?
My fear hath catched your fondness! Now I see
The mystery of your loneliness and find
Your salt tears’ head. Now to all sense ’tis gross:
You love my son. Invention is ashamed
Against the proclamation of thy passion
To say thou dost not. Therefore tell me true,
But tell me then ’tis so, for, look, thy cheeks
Confess it th’ one to th’ other, and thine eyes
See it so grossly shown in thy behaviors
That in their kind they speak it. Only sin
And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue
That truth should be suspected. Speak. Is ’t so?
If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew;
If it be not, forswear ’t; howe’er, I charge thee,
As heaven shall work in me for thine avail,
To tell me truly.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Good madam, pardon me.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Do you love my son?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Your pardon, noble mistress.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Love you my son?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Do not you love him, madam?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Go not about. My love hath in ’t a bond
Whereof the world takes note. Come, come, disclose
The state of your affection, for your passions
Have to the full appeached.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Then I confess
Here on my knee before high heaven and you
That before you and next unto high heaven
I love your son.
My friends were poor but honest; so ’s my love.
Be not offended, for it hurts not him
That he is loved of me. I follow him not
By any token of presumptuous suit,
Nor would I have him till I do deserve him,
Yet never know how that desert should be.
I know I love in vain, strive against hope,
Yet in this captious and intenible sieve
I still pour in the waters of my love
And lack not to lose still. Thus, Indian-like,
Religious in mine error, I adore
The sun that looks upon his worshipper
But knows of him no more. My dearest madam,
Let not your hate encounter with my love
For loving where you do; but if yourself,
Whose agèd honor cites a virtuous youth,
Did ever in so true a flame of liking
Wish chastely and love dearly, that your Dian
Was both herself and Love, O then give pity
To her whose state is such that cannot choose
But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
That seeks not to find that her search implies,
But riddle-like lives sweetly where she dies.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Had you not lately an intent— speak truly—
To go to Paris?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Madam, I had.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Wherefore?
Tell true.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I will tell truth, by grace itself I swear.
You know my father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading
And manifest experience had collected
For general sovereignty; and that he willed me
In heedfull’st reservation to bestow them
As notes whose faculties inclusive were
More than they were in note. Amongst the rest
There is a remedy, approved, set down,
To cure the desperate languishings whereof
The King is rendered lost.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: This was your motive for Paris, was it? Speak.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: My lord your son made me to think of this;
Else Paris, and the medicine, and the King
Had from the conversation of my thoughts
Haply been absent then.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: But think you, Helen,
If you should tender your supposèd aid,
He would receive it? He and his physicians
Are of a mind: he that they cannot help him,
They that they cannot help. How shall they credit
A poor unlearnèd virgin, when the schools
Emboweled of their doctrine have left off
The danger to itself?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: There’s something in ’t
More than my father’s skill, which was the great’st
Of his profession, that his good receipt
Shall for my legacy be sanctified
By th’ luckiest stars in heaven; and would your Honor
But give me leave to try success, I’d venture
The well-lost life of mine on his Grace’s cure
By such a day, an hour.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Dost thou believe ’t?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Ay, madam, knowingly.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love,
Means and attendants, and my loving greetings
To those of mine in court. I’ll stay at home
And pray God’s blessing into thy attempt.
Be gone tomorrow, and be sure of this:
What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Flourish cornets. Enter the King, attended, with divers young Lords, taking leave for the Florentine war; Bertram Count Rossillion, and Parolles.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Farewell, young lords. These warlike principles
Do not throw from you.— And you, my lords, farewell.
Share the advice betwixt you. If both gain all,
The gift doth stretch itself as ’tis received
And is enough for both.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: ’Tis our hope, sir,
After well-entered soldiers, to return
And find your Grace in health.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: No, no, it cannot be. And yet my heart
Will not confess he owes the malady
That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords.
Whether I live or die, be you the sons
Of worthy Frenchmen. Let higher Italy—
Those bated that inherit but the fall
Of the last monarchy— see that you come
Not to woo honor but to wed it. When
The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek,
That fame may cry you loud. I say farewell.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: Health at your bidding serve your Majesty!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them.
They say our French lack language to deny
If they demand. Beware of being captives
Before you serve.

sp.speaker: LORDS
sp.l: Our hearts receive your warnings.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Farewell.— Come hither to me.

div.stage: The King speaks to Attendants, while Bertram, Parolles, and other Lords come forward.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: O my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: ’Tis not his fault, the spark.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: O, ’tis brave wars.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: Most admirable. I have seen those wars.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I am commanded here and kept a coil
With “ Too young,” and “ The next year,” and “ ’Tis too early.”

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: An thy mind stand to ’t, boy, steal away bravely.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,
Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry
Till honor be bought up, and no sword worn
But one to dance with. By heaven, I’ll steal away!

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: There’s honor in the theft.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: Commit it, count.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: I am your accessory. And so, farewell.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I grow to you, and our parting is a tortured
body.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.p: Farewell, captain.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.p: Sweet Monsieur Parolles.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin.
Good sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals.
You shall find in the regiment of the Spinii one
Captain Spurio with his cicatrice, an emblem of
war, here on his sinister cheek. It was this very
sword entrenched it. Say to him I live, and observe
his reports for me.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.p: We shall, noble captain.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Mars dote on you for his novices.
To Bertram. What will you do?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Stay the King.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble
lords. You have restrained yourself within the list
of too cold an adieu. Be more expressive to them,
for they wear themselves in the cap of the time;
there do muster true gait; eat, speak, and move
under the influence of the most received star, and,
though the devil lead the measure, such are to be
followed. After them, and take a more dilated
farewell.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: And I will do so.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Worthy fellows, and like to prove most
sinewy swordmen.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I’ll fee thee to stand up.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Then here’s a man stands that has brought his pardon.
I would you had kneeled, my lord, to ask me mercy,
And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I would I had, so I had broke thy pate
And asked thee mercy for ’t.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Good faith, across.
But, my good lord, ’tis thus: will you be cured
Of your infirmity?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: O, will you eat
No grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you will
My noble grapes, an if my royal fox
Could reach them. I have seen a medicine
That’s able to breathe life into a stone,
Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary
With sprightly fire and motion, whose simple touch
Is powerful to araise King Pippen, nay,
To give great Charlemagne a pen in ’s hand
And write to her a love line.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: What “ her” is this?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Why, Doctor She. My lord, there’s one arrived,
If you will see her. Now, by my faith and honor,
If seriously I may convey my thoughts
In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
With one that in her sex, her years, profession,
Wisdom, and constancy hath amazed me more
Than I dare blame my weakness. Will you see her—
For that is her demand— and know her business?
That done, laugh well at me.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Now, good Lafew,
Bring in the admiration, that we with thee
May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
By wond’ring how thou took’st it.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Nay, I’ll fit you,
And not be all day neither.

div.stage: He goes to bring in Helen.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Nay, come your ways.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: This haste hath wings indeed.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: Nay, come your ways.
This is his Majesty. Say your mind to him.
A traitor you do look like, but such traitors
His Majesty seldom fears. I am Cressid’s uncle
That dare leave two together. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Ay, my good lord,
Gerard de Narbon was my father,
In what he did profess well found.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I knew him.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: The rather will I spare my praises towards him.
Knowing him is enough. On ’s bed of death
Many receipts he gave me, chiefly one
Which, as the dearest issue of his practice,
And of his old experience th’ only darling,
He bade me store up as a triple eye,
Safer than mine own two, more dear. I have so,
And hearing your high Majesty is touched
With that malignant cause wherein the honor
Of my dear father’s gift stands chief in power,
I come to tender it and my appliance
With all bound humbleness.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: We thank you, maiden,
But may not be so credulous of cure,
When our most learnèd doctors leave us and
The congregated college have concluded
That laboring art can never ransom nature
From her inaidible estate. I say we must not
So stain our judgment or corrupt our hope
To prostitute our past-cure malady
To empirics, or to dissever so
Our great self and our credit to esteem
A senseless help when help past sense we deem.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: My duty, then, shall pay me for my pains.
I will no more enforce mine office on you,
Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
A modest one to bear me back again.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I cannot give thee less, to be called grateful.
Thou thought’st to help me, and such thanks I give
As one near death to those that wish him live.
But what at full I know, thou know’st no part,
I knowing all my peril, thou no art.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: What I can do can do no hurt to try
Since you set up your rest ’gainst remedy.
He that of greatest works is finisher
Oft does them by the weakest minister.
So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown
When judges have been babes. Great floods have flown
From simple sources, and great seas have dried
When miracles have by the great’st been denied.
Oft expectation fails, and most oft there
Where most it promises, and oft it hits
Where hope is coldest and despair most shifts.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I must not hear thee. Fare thee well, kind maid.
Thy pains, not used, must by thyself be paid.
Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Inspirèd merit so by breath is barred.
It is not so with Him that all things knows
As ’tis with us that square our guess by shows;
But most it is presumption in us when
The help of heaven we count the act of men.
Dear sir, to my endeavors give consent.
Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an impostor that proclaim
Myself against the level of mine aim,
But know I think and think I know most sure
My art is not past power nor you past cure.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Art thou so confident? Within what space
Hop’st thou my cure?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: The greatest grace lending grace,
Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring;
Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
Moist Hesperus hath quenched her sleepy lamp;
Or four and twenty times the pilot’s glass
Hath told the thievish minutes, how they pass,
What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly,
Health shall live free, and sickness freely die.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Upon thy certainty and confidence
What dar’st thou venture?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Tax of impudence,
A strumpet’s boldness, a divulgèd shame;
Traduced by odious ballads, my maiden’s name
Seared otherwise; nay, worse of worst, extended
With vilest torture let my life be ended.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Methinks in thee some blessèd spirit doth speak
His powerful sound within an organ weak,
And what impossibility would slay
In common sense, sense saves another way.
Thy life is dear, for all that life can rate
Worth name of life in thee hath estimate:
Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all
That happiness and prime can happy call.
Thou this to hazard needs must intimate
Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
Sweet practicer, thy physic I will try,
That ministers thine own death if I die.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: If I break time or flinch in property
Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die,
And well deserved. Not helping, death’s my fee.
But if I help, what do you promise me?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Make thy demand.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: But will you make it even?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Ay, by my scepter and my hopes of heaven.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command.
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
My low and humble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy state;
But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know
Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Here is my hand. The premises observed,
Thy will by my performance shall be served.
So make the choice of thy own time, for I,
Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely.
More should I question thee, and more I must,
Though more to know could not be more to trust:
From whence thou cam’st, how tended on; but rest
Unquestioned welcome and undoubted blessed.—
Give me some help here, ho!— If thou proceed
As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed.

div.stage: Flourish. They exit, the King assisted.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Come on, sir. I shall now put you to the
height of your breeding.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught. I
know my business is but to the court.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
“ To the court”? Why, what place make you
special when you put off that with such contempt?
“ But to the court”?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners,
he may easily put it off at court. He that cannot
make a leg, put off ’s cap, kiss his hand, and
say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap;
and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were
not for the court. But, for me, I have an answer
will serve all men.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Marry, that’s a bountiful answer that fits all
questions.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
It is like a barber’s chair that fits all buttocks:
the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawn-buttock,
or any buttock.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney,
as your French crown for your taffety punk, as
Tib’s rush for Tom’s forefinger, as a pancake for
Shrove Tuesday, a morris for May Day, as the nail
to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding
quean to a wrangling knave, as the nun’s lip to the
friar’s mouth, nay, as the pudding to his skin.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness
for all questions?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
From below your duke to beneath your constable,
it will fit any question.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
It must be an answer of most monstrous
size that must fit all demands.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned
should speak truth of it. Here it is, and all that
belongs to ’t. Ask me if I am a courtier; it shall do
you no harm to learn.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
To be young again, if we could! I will be a
fool in question, hoping to be the wiser by your
answer. I pray you, sir, are you a courtier?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
O Lord, sir!— There’s a simple putting off. More,
more, a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Sir, I am a poor friend of yours that loves
you.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: O Lord, sir!— Thick, thick. Spare not me.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely
meat.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: O Lord, sir!— Nay, put me to ’t, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: O Lord, sir!— Spare not me.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Do you cry “ O Lord, sir!” at your whipping,
and “ spare not me”? Indeed your “ O Lord, sir!” is
very sequent to your whipping. You would answer
very well to a whipping if you were but bound to ’t.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I ne’er had worse luck in my life in my “ O Lord,
sir!” I see things may serve long but not serve ever.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
I play the noble huswife with the time to
entertain it so merrily with a fool.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: O Lord, sir!— Why, there ’t serves well again.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: An end, sir. To your business. Give Helen this,
And urge her to a present answer back.
Commend me to my kinsmen and my son.
This is not much.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Not much commendation to them?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Not much employment for you. You understand me.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Most fruitfully. I am there before my legs.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Haste you again.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Count Bertram, Lafew, and Parolles.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
They say miracles are past, and we have our
philosophical persons to make modern and familiar
things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it
that we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves
into seeming knowledge when we should
submit ourselves to an unknown fear.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Why, ’tis the rarest argument of wonder that
hath shot out in our latter times.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: And so ’tis.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: To be relinquished of the artists—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: So I say, both of Galen and Paracelsus.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Of all the learned and authentic fellows—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Right, so I say.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: That gave him out incurable—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Why, there ’tis. So say I too.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Not to be helped.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Right, as ’twere a man assured of a—

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Uncertain life and sure death.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Just. You say well. So would I have said.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: I may truly say it is a novelty to the world.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
It is indeed. If you will have it in showing,
you shall read it in what-do-you-call there.

div.stage: He points to a paper in Lafew’s hand.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.q:
A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly
actor.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: That’s it. I would have said the very same.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Why, your dolphin is not lustier. ’Fore me, I
speak in respect—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Nay, ’tis strange, ’tis very strange; that is the
brief and the tedious of it; and he’s of a most facinorous
spirit that will not acknowledge it to be
the—

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Very hand of heaven.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Ay, so I say.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: In a most weak—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
And debile minister. Great power, great
transcendence, which should indeed give us a further
use to be made than alone the recov’ry of the
King, as to be—

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Generally thankful.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I would have said it. You say well. Here
comes the King.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Lustig, as the Dutchman says. I’ll like a maid
the better whilst I have a tooth in my head. Why,
he’s able to lead her a coranto.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Mort du vinaigre! Is not this Helen?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: ’Fore God, I think so.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Go, call before me all the lords in court.
Sit, my preserver, by thy patient’s side,
And with this healthful hand, whose banished sense
Thou hast repealed, a second time receive
The confirmation of my promised gift,
Which but attends thy naming.
sp.stage: Enter three or four Court Lords.
sp.l: Fair maid, send forth thine eye. This youthful parcel
Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,
O’er whom both sovereign power and father’s voice
I have to use. Thy frank election make.
Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress
Fall when Love please! Marry, to each but one.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.l: I’d give bay Curtal and his furniture
My mouth no more were broken than these boys’
And writ as little beard.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Peruse them well.
Not one of those but had a noble father.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Heaven hath through me restored the King to health.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: We understand it and thank heaven for you.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest
That I protest I simply am a maid.—
Please it your Majesty, I have done already.
The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me:
“ We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,
Let the white death sit on thy cheek forever;
We’ll ne’er come there again.”

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Make choice and see.
Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,
And to imperial Love, that god most high,
Do my sighs stream.
sp.stage: She addresses her to a Lord.
sp.l: Sir, will you hear my suit?

sp.speaker: FIRST COURT LORD
sp.l: And grant it.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Thanks, sir. All the rest is mute.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
I had rather be in this choice than
throw ambs-ace for my life.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: The honor, sir, that flames in your fair eyes
Before I speak too threat’ningly replies.
Love make your fortunes twenty times above
Her that so wishes, and her humble love.

sp.speaker: SECOND COURT LORD
sp.l: No better, if you please.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: My wish receive,
Which great Love grant, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Do all they deny her? An they were sons
of mine, I’d have them whipped, or I would send
them to th’ Turk to make eunuchs of.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Be not afraid that I your hand should take.
I’ll never do you wrong, for your own sake.
Blessing upon your vows, and in your bed
Find fairer fortune if you ever wed.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
HELEN
sp.l: You are too young, too happy, and too good
To make yourself a son out of my blood.

sp.speaker: FOURTH COURT LORD
sp.l: Fair one, I think not so.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
There’s one grape yet. I am sure thy
father drunk wine. But if thou be’st not an ass, I
am a youth of fourteen; I have known thee already.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I dare not say I take you, but I give
Me and my service ever whilst I live
Into your guiding power.— This is the man.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Why then, young Bertram, take her. She’s thy wife.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: My wife, my liege? I shall beseech your Highness
In such a business give me leave to use
The help of mine own eyes.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Know’st thou not, Bertram,
What she has done for me?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Yes, my good lord,
But never hope to know why I should marry her.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Thou know’st she has raised me from my sickly bed.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down
Must answer for your raising? I know her well;
She had her breeding at my father’s charge.
A poor physician’s daughter my wife? Disdain
Rather corrupt me ever!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: ’Tis only title thou disdain’st in her, the which
I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods,
Of color, weight, and heat, poured all together,
Would quite confound distinction, yet stands off
In differences so mighty. If she be
All that is virtuous, save what thou dislik’st—
“ A poor physician’s daughter”— thou dislik’st
Of virtue for the name. But do not so.
From lowest place whence virtuous things proceed,
The place is dignified by th’ doer’s deed.
Where great additions swell ’s, and virtue none,
It is a dropsied honor. Good alone
Is good, without a name; vileness is so;
The property by what it is should go,
Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair;
In these to nature she’s immediate heir,
And these breed honor. That is honor’s scorn
Which challenges itself as honor’s born
And is not like the sire. Honors thrive
When rather from our acts we them derive
Than our foregoers. The mere word’s a slave
Debauched on every tomb, on every grave
A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb
Where dust and damned oblivion is the tomb
Of honored bones indeed. What should be said?
If thou canst like this creature as a maid,
I can create the rest. Virtue and she
Is her own dower, honor and wealth from me.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do ’t.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Thou wrong’st thyself if thou shouldst strive to choose.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: That you are well restored, my lord, I’m glad.
Let the rest go.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: My honor’s at the stake, which to defeat
I must produce my power.— Here, take her hand,
Proud, scornful boy, unworthy this good gift,
That dost in vile misprision shackle up
My love and her desert; that canst not dream
We, poising us in her defective scale,
Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know
It is in us to plant thine honor where
We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt;
Obey our will, which travails in thy good.
Believe not thy disdain, but presently
Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
Which both thy duty owes and our power claims,
Or I will throw thee from my care forever
Into the staggers and the careless lapse
Of youth and ignorance, both my revenge and hate
Loosing upon thee in the name of justice
Without all terms of pity. Speak. Thine answer.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Pardon, my gracious lord, for I submit
My fancy to your eyes. When I consider
What great creation and what dole of honor
Flies where you bid it, I find that she which late
Was in my nobler thoughts most base is now
The praisèd of the King, who, so ennobled,
Is as ’twere born so.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Take her by the hand,
And tell her she is thine, to whom I promise
A counterpoise, if not to thy estate,
A balance more replete.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I take her hand.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Good fortune and the favor of the King
Smile upon this contract, whose ceremony
Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief
And be performed tonight. The solemn feast
Shall more attend upon the coming space,
Expecting absent friends. As thou lov’st her
Thy love’s to me religious; else, does err.

div.stage: They exit. Parolles and Lafew stay behind, commenting of this wedding.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Do you hear, monsieur? A word with you.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Your pleasure, sir.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Your lord and master did well to make his
recantation.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: “ Recantation”? My “ lord”? My “ master”?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Ay. Is it not a language I speak?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
A most harsh one, and not to be understood
without bloody succeeding. My “ master”?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Are you companion to the Count Rossillion?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: To any count, to all counts, to what is man.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
To what is count’s man. Count’s master is of
another style.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are
too old.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man, to which
title age cannot bring thee.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a
pretty wise fellow; thou didst make tolerable vent
of thy travel; it might pass. Yet the scarves and the
bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me
from believing thee a vessel of too great a burden.
I have now found thee. When I lose thee again, I
care not. Yet art thou good for nothing but taking
up, and that thou ’rt scarce worth.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity
upon thee—

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Do not plunge thyself too far in anger lest thou
hasten thy trial, which if— Lord have mercy on
thee for a hen! So, my good window of lattice, fare
thee well; thy casement I need not open, for I look
through thee. Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
My lord, you give me most egregious
indignity.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, and thou art worthy of it.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Yes, good faith, ev’ry dram of it, and I will not
bate thee a scruple.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Well, I shall be wiser.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Ev’n as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to
pull at a smack o’ th’ contrary. If ever thou be’st
bound in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find
what it is to be proud of thy bondage. I have a
desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or
rather my knowledge, that I may say in the default
“ He is a man I know.”

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
My lord, you do me most insupportable
vexation.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
I would it were hell pains for thy sake, and my
poor doing eternal; for doing I am past, as I will by
thee in what motion age will give me leave.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace
off me. Scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, I must
be patient; there is no fettering of authority. I’ll
beat him, by my life, if I can meet him with any
convenience, an he were double and double a lord.
I’ll have no more pity of his age than I would have
of— I’ll beat him, an if I could but meet him again.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Sirrah, your lord and master’s married. There’s
news for you: you have a new mistress.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I most unfeignedly beseech your Lordship
to make some reservation of your wrongs. He is
my good lord; whom I serve above is my master.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Who? God?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
The devil it is that’s thy master. Why dost thou
garter up thy arms o’ this fashion? Dost make hose
of thy sleeves? Do other servants so? Thou wert
best set thy lower part where thy nose stands. By
mine honor, if I were but two hours younger, I’d
beat thee. Methink’st thou art a general offense,
and every man should beat thee. I think thou wast
created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
This is hard and undeserved measure, my
lord.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Go to, sir. You were beaten in Italy for picking a
kernel out of a pomegranate. You are a vagabond,
and no true traveler. You are more saucy with
lords and honorable personages than the commission
of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry.
You are not worth another word; else I’d call you
knave. I leave you.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Good, very good! It is so, then. Good, very
good. Let it be concealed awhile.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Undone, and forfeited to cares forever!

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: What’s the matter, sweetheart?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn,
I will not bed her.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: What, what, sweetheart?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: O my Parolles, they have married me!
I’ll to the Tuscan wars and never bed her.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits
the tread of a man’s foot. To th’ wars!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
There’s letters from my mother. What th’
import is I know not yet.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Ay, that would be known. To th’ wars, my
boy, to th’ wars!
sp.l: He wears his honor in a box unseen
That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home,
Spending his manly marrow in her arms
Which should sustain the bound and high curvet
Of Mars’s fiery steed. To other regions!
France is a stable, we that dwell in ’t jades.
Therefore, to th’ war!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: It shall be so. I’ll send her to my house,
Acquaint my mother with my hate to her
And wherefore I am fled, write to the King
That which I durst not speak. His present gift
Shall furnish me to those Italian fields
Where noble fellows strike. Wars is no strife
To the dark house and the detested wife.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: Will this capriccio hold in thee? Art sure?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Go with me to my chamber, and advise me.
I’ll send her straight away. Tomorrow
I’ll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: Why, these balls bound; there’s noise in it. ’Tis hard.
A young man married is a man that’s marred.
Therefore away, and leave her bravely. Go.
The King has done you wrong, but hush, ’tis so.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Helen with a paper, and Fool.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: My mother greets me kindly. Is she well?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
She is not well, but yet she has her health. She’s
very merry, but yet she is not well. But, thanks be
given, she’s very well and wants nothing i’ th’ world,
but yet she is not well.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
If she be very well, what does she ail that she’s
not very well?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Truly, she’s very well indeed, but for two things.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What two things?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
One, that she’s not in heaven, whither God send
her quickly; the other, that she’s in Earth, from
whence God send her quickly.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Bless you, my fortunate lady.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p:
I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine
own good fortunes.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
You had my prayers to lead them on, and to
keep them on have them still.— O my knave, how
does my old lady?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I
would she did as you say.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Why, I say nothing.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Marry, you are the wiser man, for many a man’s
tongue shakes out his master’s undoing. To say
nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to
have nothing is to be a great part of your title,
which is within a very little of nothing.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Away. Thou ’rt a knave.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
You should have said, sir, “ Before a knave,
thou ’rt a knave”; that’s “ Before me, thou ’rt a
knave.” This had been truth, sir.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Go to. Thou art a witty fool. I have found
thee.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Did you find me in yourself, sir, or were you
taught to find me?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
The search, sir, was profitable, and much fool
may you find in you, even to the world’s pleasure
and the increase of laughter.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: A good knave, i’ faith, and well fed.
Madam, my lord will go away tonight;
A very serious business calls on him.
The great prerogative and rite of love,
Which as your due time claims, he does acknowledge
But puts it off to a compelled restraint,
Whose want and whose delay is strewed with sweets,
Which they distill now in the curbèd time
To make the coming hour o’erflow with joy
And pleasure drown the brim.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: What’s his will else?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: That you will take your instant leave o’ th’ King
And make this haste as your own good proceeding,
Strengthened with what apology you think
May make it probable need.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: What more commands he?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: That, having this obtained, you presently
Attend his further pleasure.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: In everything I wait upon his will.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: I shall report it so.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I pray you, come, sirrah.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
But I hope your Lordship thinks not him a
soldier.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: You have it from his own deliverance.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: And by other warranted testimony.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
Then my dial goes not true. I took this lark for
a bunting.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I do assure you, my lord, he is very great in
knowledge and accordingly valiant.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
I have then sinned against his experience and
transgressed against his valor, and my state that
way is dangerous since I cannot yet find in my
heart to repent. Here he comes. I pray you make us
friends. I will pursue the amity.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: These things shall be done, sir.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p: Pray you, sir, who’s his tailor?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
O, I know him well. Ay, sir, he, sir, ’s a good
workman, a very good tailor.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Is she gone to the King?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Will she away tonight?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: As you’ll have her.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure,
Given order for our horses, and tonight,
When I should take possession of the bride,
End ere I do begin.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
A good traveler is something at the latter
end of a dinner, but one that lies three thirds,
and uses a known truth to pass a thousand nothings
with, should be once heard and thrice beaten.—
God save you, captain.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Is there any unkindness
between my lord and you, monsieur?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I know not how I have deserved to run into
my lord’s displeasure.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
You have made shift to run into ’t, boots and
spurs and all, like him that leapt into the custard;
and out of it you’ll run again rather than suffer
question for your residence.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.

sp.speaker: LAFEW
sp.p:
And shall do so ever, though I took him at ’s
prayers. Fare you well, my lord, and believe this of
me: there can be no kernel in this light nut. The
soul of this man is his clothes. Trust him not in
matter of heavy consequence. I have kept of them
tame and know their natures.— Farewell, monsieur.
I have spoken better of you than you have or
will to deserve at my hand, but we must do good
against evil.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: An idle lord, I swear.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I think not so.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Why, do you not know him?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Yes, I do know him well, and common speech
Gives him a worthy pass.
Here comes my clog.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I have, sir, as I was commanded from you,
Spoke with the King and have procured his leave
For present parting. Only he desires
Some private speech with you.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I shall obey his will.
You must not marvel, Helen, at my course,
Which holds not color with the time, nor does
The ministration and requirèd office
On my particular. Prepared I was not
For such a business; therefore am I found
So much unsettled. This drives me to entreat you
That presently you take your way for home,
And rather muse than ask why I entreat you;
For my respects are better than they seem,
And my appointments have in them a need
Greater than shows itself at the first view
To you that know them not.
This to my mother.
’Twill be two days ere I shall see you, so
I leave you to your wisdom.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Sir, I can nothing say
But that I am your most obedient servant—

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Come, come, no more of that.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: And ever shall
With true observance seek to eke out that
Wherein toward me my homely stars have failed
To equal my great fortune.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Let that go.
My haste is very great. Farewell. Hie home.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Pray, sir, your pardon.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Well, what would you say?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe,
Nor dare I say ’tis mine— and yet it is—
But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal
What law does vouch mine own.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Something, and scarce so much; nothing, indeed.
I would not tell you what I would, my lord. Faith, yes:
Strangers and foes do sunder and not kiss.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: I pray you stay not, but in haste to horse.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.—
Where are my other men?— Monsieur, farewell.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Go thou toward home, where I will never come
Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum.—
Away, and for our flight.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.l: Bravely, coraggio!

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Flourish. Enter the Duke of Florence, the two French Lords, with a troop of Soldiers.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: So that from point to point now have you heard
The fundamental reasons of this war,
Whose great decision hath much blood let forth
And more thirsts after.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: Holy seems the quarrel
Upon your Grace’s part, black and fearful
On the opposer.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
Would in so just a business shut his bosom
Against our borrowing prayers.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Good my lord,
The reasons of our state I cannot yield
But like a common and an outward man
That the great figure of a council frames
By self-unable motion; therefore dare not
Say what I think of it, since I have found
Myself in my incertain grounds to fail
As often as I guessed.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Be it his pleasure.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: But I am sure the younger of our nation,
That surfeit on their ease, will day by day
Come here for physic.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Welcome shall they be,
And all the honors that can fly from us
Shall on them settle. You know your places well.
When better fall, for your avails they fell.
Tomorrow to th’ field.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Countess, with a paper, and Fool.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
It hath happened all as I would have had it,
save that he comes not along with her.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very
melancholy man.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: By what observance, I pray you?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Why, he will look upon his boot and sing, mend
the ruff and sing, ask questions and sing, pick his
teeth and sing. I know a man that had this trick of
melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Let me see what he writes and when he
means to come.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court. Our
old lings and our Isbels o’ th’ country are nothing
like your old ling and your Isbels o’ th’ court. The
brains of my Cupid’s knocked out, and I begin to
love as an old man loves money, with no stomach.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: E’en that you have there.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.q:
I have sent you a daughter-in-law.
She hath recovered the King and undone me. I have
wedded her, not bedded her, and sworn to make the
“ not” eternal. You shall hear I am run away. Know it
before the report come. If there be breadth enough in
the world, I will hold a long distance. My duty to
you.
Your unfortunate son,
Bertram.
sp.l: This is not well, rash and unbridled boy:
To fly the favors of so good a king,
To pluck his indignation on thy head
By the misprizing of a maid too virtuous
For the contempt of empire.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
O madam, yonder is heavy news within, between
two soldiers and my young lady.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some
comfort. Your son will not be killed so soon as I
thought he would.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Why should he be killed?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he
does. The danger is in standing to ’t; that’s the loss
of men, though it be the getting of children. Here
they come will tell you more. For my part, I only
hear your son was run away.

div.stage: Enter Helen, with a paper, and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Save you, good madam.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Madam, my lord is gone, forever gone.

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Do not say so.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Think upon patience, pray you.— Gentlemen,
I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief
That the first face of neither on the start
Can woman me unto ’t. Where is my son, I pray you?

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Madam, he’s gone to serve the Duke of Florence.
We met him thitherward, for thence we came,
And, after some dispatch in hand at court,
Thither we bend again.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Look on his letter, madam; here’s my passport.
sp.q:
When thou canst get the ring upon
my finger, which never shall come off, and show me
a child begotten of thy body that I am father to, then
call me husband. But in such a “ then” I write a
“ never.”
sp.l: This is a dreadful sentence.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Brought you this letter, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Ay, madam,
And for the contents’ sake are sorry for our pains.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: I prithee, lady, have a better cheer.
If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine,
Thou robb’st me of a moiety. He was my son,
But I do wash his name out of my blood,
And thou art all my child.— Towards Florence is he?

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: And to be a soldier?

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Such is his noble purpose, and, believe ’t,
The Duke will lay upon him all the honor
That good convenience claims.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Return you thither?

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

sp.speaker: HELEN

l.q: Till I have no wife I have nothing in France.

sp.l: ’Tis bitter.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Find you that there?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.l: ’Tis but the boldness of his hand, haply,
Which his heart was not consenting to.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Nothing in France until he have no wife!
There’s nothing here that is too good for him
But only she, and she deserves a lord
That twenty such rude boys might tend upon
And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him?

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.l: A servant only, and a gentleman
Which I have sometime known.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Parolles was it not?

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Ay, my good lady, he.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness.
My son corrupts a well-derivèd nature
With his inducement.

sp.speaker: FIRST GENTLEMAN
sp.l: Indeed, good lady,
The fellow has a deal of that too much
Which holds him much to have.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: You’re welcome, gentlemen.
I will entreat you when you see my son
To tell him that his sword can never win
The honor that he loses. More I’ll entreat you
Written to bear along.

sp.speaker: SECOND GENTLEMAN
sp.l: We serve you, madam,
In that and all your worthiest affairs.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Not so, but as we change our courtesies.
Will you draw near?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: “ Till I have no wife I have nothing in France.”
Nothing in France until he has no wife.
Thou shalt have none, Rossillion, none in France.
Then hast thou all again. Poor lord, is ’t I
That chase thee from thy country and expose
Those tender limbs of thine to the event
Of the none-sparing war? And is it I
That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou
Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark
Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers
That ride upon the violent speed of fire,
Fly with false aim; move the still-’pearing air
That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord.
Whoever shoots at him, I set him there;
Whoever charges on his forward breast,
I am the caitiff that do hold him to ’t;
And though I kill him not, I am the cause
His death was so effected. Better ’twere
I met the ravin lion when he roared
With sharp constraint of hunger; better ’twere
That all the miseries which nature owes
Were mine at once. No, come thou home, Rossillion,
Whence honor but of danger wins a scar,
As oft it loses all. I will be gone.
My being here it is that holds thee hence.
Shall I stay here to do ’t? No, no, although
The air of paradise did fan the house
And angels officed all. I will be gone,
That pitiful rumor may report my flight
To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day;
For with the dark, poor thief, I’ll steal away.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Flourish. Enter the Duke of Florence, Bertram Count Rossillion, Drum and Trumpets, Soldiers, Parolles.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: The general of our horse thou art, and we,
Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence
Upon thy promising fortune.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: Sir, it is
A charge too heavy for my strength, but yet
We’ll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
To th’ extreme edge of hazard.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Then go thou forth,
And Fortune play upon thy prosperous helm
As thy auspicious mistress.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.l: This very day,
Great Mars, I put myself into thy file.
Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove
A lover of thy drum, hater of love.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Countess and Steward, with a paper.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Alas! And would you take the letter of her?
Might you not know she would do as she has done
By sending me a letter? Read it again.

lg.l: I am Saint Jaques’ pilgrim, thither gone.
Ambitious love hath so in me offended
That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon,
With sainted vow my faults to have amended.
Write, write, that from the bloody course of war
My dearest master, your dear son, may hie.
Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far
His name with zealous fervor sanctify.
His taken labors bid him me forgive;
I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth
From courtly friends, with camping foes to live
Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth.
He is too good and fair for death and me,
Whom I myself embrace to set him free.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!
Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much
As letting her pass so. Had I spoke with her,
I could have well diverted her intents,
Which thus she hath prevented.

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.l: Pardon me, madam.
If I had given you this at overnight,
She might have been o’erta’en. And yet she writes
Pursuit would be but vain.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: What angel shall
Bless this unworthy husband? He cannot thrive
Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear
And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath
Of greatest justice. Write, write, Rinaldo,
To this unworthy husband of his wife.
Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
That he does weigh too light. My greatest grief,
Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
Dispatch the most convenient messenger.
When haply he shall hear that she is gone,
He will return; and hope I may that she,
Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,
Led hither by pure love. Which of them both
Is dearest to me, I have no skill in sense
To make distinction. Provide this messenger.
My heart is heavy, and mine age is weak.
Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: A tucket afar off. Enter old Widow of Florence, her daughter Diana, and Mariana, with other Citizens.

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.p:
Nay, come, for if they do approach the city, we
shall lose all the sight.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
They say the French count has done most honorable
service.

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.p:
It is reported that he has taken their great’st
commander, and that with his own hand he slew
the Duke’s brother. A trumpet sounds. We have
lost our labor. They are gone a contrary way. Hark,
you may know by their trumpets.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.p:
Come, let’s return again and suffice ourselves
with the report of it.— Well, Diana, take heed of
this French earl. The honor of a maid is her name,
and no legacy is so rich as honesty.

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.p:
I have told my neighbor how you
have been solicited by a gentleman, his
companion.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.p:
I know that knave, hang him! One Parolles, a
filthy officer he is in those suggestions for the
young earl.— Beware of them, Diana. Their promises,
enticements, oaths, tokens, and all these
engines of lust are not the things they go under.
Many a maid hath been seduced by them; and
the misery is example that so terrible shows in the
wrack of maidenhood cannot for all that dissuade
succession, but that they are limed with the twigs
that threatens them. I hope I need not to advise
you further, but I hope your own grace will keep
you where you are, though there were no further
danger known but the modesty which is so lost.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: You shall not need to fear me.

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.p: I hope so.

Look, here comes a pilgrim. I know she will lie at
my house; thither they send one another. I’ll question
her.— God save you, pilgrim. Whither are
bound?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: To Saint Jaques le Grand.
Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.l: At the Saint Francis here beside the port.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Is this the way?

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.l: Ay, marry, is ’t.— Hark you, they come this way.—
If you will tarry, holy pilgrim,
But till the troops come by,
I will conduct you where you shall be lodged,
The rather for I think I know your hostess
As ample as myself.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: Is it yourself?

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.l: If you shall please so, pilgrim.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.l: You came I think from France?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: I did so.

sp.speaker: WIDOW
sp.l: Here you shall see a countryman of yours
That has done worthy service.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.l: His name, I pray you?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.l: The Count Rossillion. Know you such a one?

sp.speaker: HELEN
